questions.text:
What of the following instruments are used in the caesarean section?


	Bard-Parker blade
	Doyen's retractor
	Cusco's speculum
	Allis forceps
	Shirodkar's uterine clamp
	Green Armytage forceps
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 2, 4, 6

Explanation: The correct answer is 1, 2, 4, 6 used in the cesarean section.

The instruments used in a caesarean section include:

(1) Bard-Parker Blade: Used for making precise abdominal, skin and subcutaneous tissue incisions.

(2) Doyen's Retractor: Applied to retract back the edges of the incision or tissue as well as the bladder for better exposure of the lower uterine segment during cesarean section.

(4) Allis Forceps: Typically used for securely grasping and holding tissues (e.g., peritoneum, rectus sheath, vaginal mucosa).

(6) Green Armytage Forceps: Utilized specifically in gynaecological surgeries, including caesarean sections, to compress a wide area and control bleeding as a hemostat.

(3) Cusco’s Speculum (Option B & D) is a self-retaining bivalve instrument used for visualizing the cervix, vaginal fornices, and performing procedures like Pap smears.

(5) Shirodkar's uterine clamp (Option A & B) is a surgical instrument used in gynecological procedures, such as sling surgeries and tubal procedures, to securely grasp and stabilize the uterus.

questions.text: Urinary tract infection in a pregnant lady in her 2nd trimester is best defined as:

choices.text: Growth of 10^3 coliform in suprapubic sample
Growth of 10^5 coliform in voided urine sample
Frequency with dysuria with positive nitrite and leucoesterase dipstick test

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Growth of 10^5 coliform in voided urine sample

 

Explanation:

  • A urinary tract infection (UTI) in a pregnant woman, especially in the 2nd trimester, is defined by a positive urine culture showing a growth of >100,000 colony-forming units (CFUs) of bacteria, typically coliforms such as E. coli, in a voided urine sample. (Option A ruled out)
  • Urine culture is considered the gold standard for diagnosing UTIs in pregnancy. UTIs can range from asymptomatic bacteriuria to symptomatic infections like cystitis or pyelonephritis.

 

Frequency with dysuria with >3 WBC/HPF (Option C): While the presence of white blood cells (WBCs) in the urine indicates infection or inflammation (pyuria), this alone is not enough to define a UTI. The presence of symptoms like dysuria and WBCs along with a positive urine culture is necessary for diagnosis.

 

Frequency with dysuria with positive nitrite and leucoesterase dipstick test (Option D): While a positive dipstick test for nitrites and leukocyte esterase can suggest a UTI, it is not definitive. A urine culture showing bacterial growth of 10^5 CFUs is the most reliable method for diagnosis.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy. Her INR is 3. What is the appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Stop warfarin and start LMWH

Explanation:

  • Patients who have undergone heart valve replacement with a prosthetic mechanical valve require lasting anticoagulation.
  • Warfarin is not recommended during pregnancy as it can cause birth defects (teratogenicity) during the first trimester and hemorrhagic complications during about 2 to 4 weeks before delivery.
  • LMWHs don't pass the placenta and are safer for the developing fetus.

Teratogenicity of Anticoagulants:

Medicine

FDA category

Adverse effects

Teratogenic

Use during lactation

Remark

Vitamin K antagonists (warfarin)

X

Teratogenicity, fetal bleeding complications

Yes

Allowed: Small amounts of metabolites pass into breast milk

-

Heparin (UFH)

C

Bone demineralization, osteoporosis, fractures in mother, risk of HIT

No

Allowed

-

LMWH

B

Lower risk of HIT and osteoporosis than UFH

No

Allowed

-

Danaparoid

B

-

No

Allowed

-

Incorrect Options:

Heparin anticoagulants (Option B) are less effective than VKAs for anticoagulation with mechanical heart valves, leaving the pregnant patient more vulnerable to a thrombotic event.

Continuing warfarin use (Option C) in early pregnancy can increase the chance of miscarriage and bleeding in the baby's brain. Warfarin use in early pregnancy can affect the baby's bones and development of the face.

Combining LMWH and aspirin (Option D) can increase the risk of bleeding complications in the patient; hence, it should be avoided.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 18 weeks of gestation presents for her antenatal check-up. Her random plasma glucose level was 243 mg/dL, and thus, she was asked to undergo further tests. The fasting blood glucose levels were 146 mg/dl, and HbA1c was 7.6%. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Maturity onset diabetes of the young

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Overt diabetes

Explanation:

Overt diabetes in pregnancy is defined as hyperglycemia first recognized during pregnancy that meets the diagnostic threshold of diabetes in non-pregnant adults.

Diagnostic Criteria for Overt Diabetes (ADA Guidelines): The diagnosis can be made in a woman with any of the following:

  • A fasting plasma glucose value ≥126 mg/dl (7.0 mmol/L)
  • 2-h plasma glucose ≥200 mg/dl (11.1 mmol/l)
  • Random plasma glucose value ≥200 mg/dl (11.1 mmol/l) in the presence of symptoms
  • HbA1c ≥6.5% (48 mmol/mol)

Maturity onset diabetes of the young (Option A): While MODY can present during pregnancy, it typically has a strong family history and presents at a younger age. The absence of family history details and typical age of presentation make this diagnosis less likely.

Gestational diabetes mellitus (Option C): GDM and overt diabetes differ in severity. GDM is a less severe form of hyperglycemia (Fasting Plasma <92mg/dl and HbA1c ≥5.7-6.4%).

Latent autoimmune diabetes in adults (Option D): The case does not talk of pancreatic antibodies, and the significant hyperglycemia early in pregnancy is more consistent with overt type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 23-year-old woman who is pregnant for the first time, currently at 25 weeks gestation, and experiencing pain in the right upper quadrant of her abdomen, along with nausea and vomiting for the past two days? Her blood pressure is 104/72 mm Hg, heart rate is 72 bpm, and she has generalized swelling. A peripheral smear shows hemolysis, and the following lab values are provided:Leukocyte count: 10,500/mm3 Platelet count: 62000/mm3 Hematocrit: 26% AST: 90 IU/L
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HELLP syndrome

Explanation:

The syndrome of hemolysis with a microangiopathic blood smear, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets, as seen in the given pregnant patient, is known as HELLP syndrome.

HELLP syndrome is a severe variant of preeclampsia that can occur without significant hypertension.

The clinical manifestations supporting the diagnosis are:

  • Hemolysis evidenced by peripheral smear findings
  • Elevated liver enzymes with AST of 90 IU/L
  • Low platelets at 62,000/mm³
  • Right upper quadrant pain suggesting liver involvement
  • Normal blood pressure does not exclude diagnosis

Criteria for Diagnosis of HELLP Syndrome:

Tenesse Classification:

Haemolysis
  • Abnormal peripheral blood smear (Hemolysis)
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH > 600 IU/L)
  • Elevated bilirubin (≥ 1.2 mg/dL)
  • Decreased serum haptoglobin

Elevated Liver Enzymes
  • Elevated (AST & ALT > 70 IU/L)

Low Platelet Count
  • Platelets < 100,000/μL

Another criterion, namely the Mississippi Triple Class System, further classifies HELLP Syndrome based on the platelet counts.

Mississippi Triple Class System

Class I (severe)
  • AST & ALT > 70 IU/L
  • LDH > 600 IU/L
  • Platelets <50 x 109 /L

Class II (moderate)
  • AST & ALT > 70 IU/L
  • LDH > 600 IU/L
  • Platelets 50-100 x 109 /L

Class III (mild)
  • AST & ALT > 40 IU/L
  • LDH > 600 IU/L
  • Platelets 100-150 x 109 /L

Hepatitis B (Option B): While hepatitis B can cause elevated liver enzymes during pregnancy, it does not explain the thrombocytopenia or hemolysis. Additionally, hepatitis typically presents with jaundice and would not cause such levels of platelet reduction.

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (Option C): AFL can be differentiated from HELLP syndrome by the presence of leucocytosis, hypoglycemia, more pronounced hyperbilirubinemia, an initial lack of hemolysis, and thrombocytopenia (100 G/l), lower antithrombin levels (65%) and prolonged prothrombin times. Since these features are not present, AFL can be ruled out.

Obstetric cholestasis (Option D): The diagnosis of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP) presents primarily with pruritus and elevated bile acids, without thrombocytopenia or hemolysis.

Condition

HELLP Syndrome

Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy (AFLP)

Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy (ICP)

Main Characteristics

Hemolysis (breakdown of red blood cells), Elevated liver enzymes, Low Platelet count

Buildup of fat in the liver, liver dysfunction

Impaired bile flow, elevated bile acids, itching

Occurrence

Usually occurs in the third trimester, but can also occur postpartum

Typically occurs in the third trimester

Usually occurs in the third trimester, but can occur earlier

Symptoms

Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, headache, edema

Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, jaundice, malaise

Intense itching, especially on palms and soles

Risk to Mother

Can lead to serious complications such as liver rupture, liver failure, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

Can lead to liver failure, coagulopathy, and other complications

Generally uncomfortable but usually does not pose a significant threat to the mother's overall health

Risk to Fetus

Can lead to fetal growth restriction, preterm birth, stillbirth, placental abruption

Can lead to fetal distress, preterm birth, and stillbirth

Increased risk of adverse fetal outcomes, such as preterm birth or stillbirth

Management

Immediate medical attention required, delivery of the baby may be necessary

Urgent medical intervention required, delivery of the baby may be necessary

Symptom relief, monitoring of bile acid levels, early delivery may be considered

Complications

Liver rupture, liver failure, DIC, maternal and fetal mortality

Liver failure, coagulopathy, maternal and fetal mortality

Increased risk of preterm birth, fetal distress, stillbirth

questions.text: Which of the following conditions are associated with oligohydramnios?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Renal agenesis

Explanation:

  • Renal agenesis occurs when one or both kidneys fail to develop during embryonic development. Around the 13th week of gestation, the kidneys begin producing urine, which contributes to amniotic fluid. Impaired kidney development leads to oligohydramnios, characterized by low amniotic fluid levels, which can be detected via ultrasound and serves as a strong indicator of renal agenesis.

 

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Potter facies: Low-set ears, beaked nose, prominent epicanthic folds, downward slant to eyes
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia causing respiratory failure
  • Limb deformities
  • Reduced fetal urine excretion
  • Oligohydramnios causing fetal compression

 

Associated Complications:

  • Growth restriction
  • Limb contractures
  • Mortality
  • Delayed lung maturation
  • Inability to endure childbirth

 

Neural tube defect (Option B): Neural tube defects are associated with polyhydramnios.

Esophageal atresia (Option C): Esophageal atresia occurs due to excess amniotic fluid (polyhydramnios).

Premature birth (Option D): Premature birth is a complication of oligohydramnios, not a cause.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant female is carrying monochorionic diamniotic twins. On ultrasound examination, there is evidence of polyhydramnios in one twin and oligohydramnios in the other. What is the most likely complication?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Twin to twin transfusion syndrome

 

Explanation: Pregnant female having monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy with ultrasound showing polyhydramnios in one twin and oligohydramnios in the other, the most likely diagnosis is Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS).

 

Twin-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS):

  • TTTS in monochorionic-diamniotic twin pregnancies involves blood transfusion from a donor twin to the recipient, causing anemia and growth restriction in the donor, and polycythemia and heart failure in the recipient.
  • Presentation:
    • Donor twin: Smaller, pale, with oligohydramnios.
    • Recipient twin: Larger, with polyhydramnios and hyperviscosity.
  • Incidence: TTTS occurs in 10-15% of monochorionic twin pregnancies.
  • Pathophysiology: Unidirectional blood flow via deep arteriovenous anastomoses leads to volume depletion in the donor and excess in the recipient, causing growth restriction and hydrops.

Quintero Staging System:

  •  

Stage

Description

Stage I

Polyhydramnios in the recipient twin (deepest vertical pocket ≥8 cm) and oligohydramnios in the donor twin (deepest vertical pocket ≤2 cm), with a visible bladder in the donor twin.

Stage II

Severe oligohydramnios in the donor twin with no visible bladder.

Stage III

Critically abnormal Doppler findings, such as absent/reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery, reversed flow in the ductus venosus, or pulsatile flow in the umbilical vein in one or both twins.

Stage IV

Presence of hydrops fetalis in one or both twins, indicating severe fetal compromise.

Stage V

Demise of one or both twins.

 

  • Management:
    • Laser ablation: Targets placental anastomoses (16-26 weeks).
    • Solomon Technique: Coagulates the entire vascular equator.
    • Amnioreduction: Reduces amniotic fluid and prevents complications.
  • Complications: Preterm birth (before 34 weeks), procedure-related issues (e.g., ruptured membranes, placental abruption), and Twin Anemia-Polycythemia Sequence (TAPS).
  • Outcomes:
    • Without treatment, perinatal mortality is 70-100%.
    • After laser therapy, mortality is 30-50%, with 5-20% neurological impairment.
    • Double-twin survival is ~70%.

 

Selective Fetal Growth Restriction (sFGR) (Option A): While sFGR can occur in monochorionic twins, it doesn't typically cause the fluid imbalance (polyhydramnios in one twin and oligohydramnios in the other) seen in Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS). sFGR is more related to growth differences between twins, not amniotic fluid abnormalities.

 

Preterm Labor (Option B): Although monochorionic diamniotic pregnancies are at higher risk for preterm birth, preterm labor doesn't cause the specific fluid imbalance, characteristic of TTTS (polyhydramnios in one twin and oligohydramnios in the other).

 

Neural Tube Defects (Option D): Neural tube defects, such as spina bifida, are developmental anomalies that affect fetal development but do not cause the fluid imbalance observed in TTTS.

questions.text:
According to IADPSG, what is the cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus?

 

IADPSG: International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Group
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) > 92 mg/dL

 

Explanation: According to IADPSG, the cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus is > 92 mg/dL.

 

Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM) is a common pregnancy complication, defined as “any degree of glucose intolerance with onset or first recognition during pregnancy.”

 

IADPSG Criteria for GDM Diagnosis:

  • A 75-g glucose dose is used for an Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) in all clinical settings, including during pregnancy.
  • GDM is diagnosed if any one of the cut-offs is met:
    • Fasting Plasma Glucose (FPG): ≥ 92 mg/dL
    • 1-hour Plasma Glucose (1-h PG): ≥ 180 mg/dL
    • 2-hour Plasma Glucose (2-h PG): ≥ 153 mg/dL

questions.text: What is the dose of dexamethasone given for fetal lung maturity?

choices.text: 2 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart
2 doses of 12 mg given 24 hours apart
4 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart
4 doses of 12 mg given 12 hours apart

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) 4 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart

 

Explanation: The dose of dexamethasone given for fetal lung maturity is 4 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart.

 

Dexamethasone in Fetal Lung Maturity:

  • Accelerates fetal lung maturation and reduces the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).
  • Improves survival and reduces morbidity in preterm neonates.
  • Recommended for pregnancies at less than 34 weeks of gestation, particularly between 31 and 34 weeks.
  • Administered as 4 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart.
  • Decreases the incidence of:
    • Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)
    • Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH)
    • Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC)

questions.text:
Which of the following modalities are used for the diagnosis of placenta accreta?


	Ultrasonography
	MRI
	Angiography
	X-ray
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 1 and 2 only

 

Explanation: Ultrasonography and MRI can be used to diagnose placenta accreta.

 

Placenta Accreta Spectrum/Morbidly Adherent Placenta:

  • Occurs when the placenta is abnormally adherent to the uterine wall after childbirth.
  • It occurs due to insufficient formation of the decidua basalis and incomplete development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer.
  • It leads to abnormal invasion of trophoblasts, which hinders the placenta from separating naturally post-delivery.
  • Diagnosis is made post-delivery when manual removal of the placenta is attempted, and the plane of cleavage between the placenta and the uterine wall cannot be made out.
  • It can lead to
    • Postpartum haemorrhage
    • Infection
    • Inversion of uterus
  • Types:

Placenta accreta spectrum

Description

Placenta accreta

Villi is firmly adherent to the endometrium

Placenta increta

Villi invades the myometrium

Placenta percreta

Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa.

 

  • Investigations:
    • Ultrasonography: (1)
      • Placental lacunae
      • Thinning of the retroplacental myometrium
      • Disruption of the bladder-uterine serosal interface
      • Bridging vessels extending from the placenta to the bladder-serosal interface
      • Placental bulge causing outward distortion of the uterine contour
    • Colour Flow Doppler: Hypervascularity at the serosa-bladder interface
    • MRI: (2)
      • Uterine bulging
      • Dark intraplacental bands on T2-weighted imaging

 

  • Management of placenta accreta spectrum:

Placenta Accreta Type

Management

Partial Placenta Accreta
  • Remove as much placenta as possible.
  • Use oxytocics to control bleeding.

Total Placenta Accreta
  • Complete family: Perform hysterectomy.
  • Incomplete family:
    • Leave the placenta for autolysis within the uterus and administer antibiotics.
    • Consider uterine artery embolisation or Methotrexate therapy.

Placenta Percreta with Bladder Invasion

Perform hysterectomy with partial cystectomy.

 

Angiography (Option A & C) is not traditionally used to diagnose placenta accreta. While it has therapeutic applications, such as embolization, its use involves radiation and contrast exposure, making it unsuitable for routine diagnosis during pregnancy due to potential risks to the mother and fetus.


X-ray (Option D) is not suitable for diagnosing placenta accreta due to the risk of exposing the fetus to ionizing radiation. Additionally, X-rays cannot provide detailed images of soft tissues like the uterus and placenta, making them ineffective in identifying the abnormalities associated with placenta accreta.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation is found to have high blood pressure recording and a urine protein of 3+. Concomitant presence of which of the following symptoms would make you suspect imminent eclampsia?


	Headache
	Blurred vision
	Persistent pedal oedema
	Epigastric pain
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) 1, 2, 4

Explanation: Headache, blurred vision, persistent pedal edema, and epigastric pain are warning signs of imminent eclampsia.

The warning signs of imminent eclampsia include:

  • Blood pressure ≥160/110 on two different occasions while the patient is on bed rest
  • Proteinuria of <5 g/24 hours
  • Oliguria or anuria
  • Epigastric pain (4)
  • Headache (1) and visual symptoms (2)
  • Pulmonary edema or cyanosis
  • Sudden and generalized or persistent pedal edema (3)
  • End organ damage
  • Disturbed sleep

Visual symptoms such as blurred vision, diplopia, scotomata, and amaurosis fugax are telltale signs that the patient is entering an eclamptic state from pre-eclampsia.

Treatment:

  • Prevention of seizures with MgSO4
  • BP control with anti-hypertensives
  • If <34 weeks, corticosteroids for lung maturation
  • Termination of pregnancy is the definitive treatment

questions.text: All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except:

choices.text: Prostaglandins play an important role; Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostaglandin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia
Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels, and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia
Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis, and hemorrhage and organ damage seen in preeclampsia
Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in sFlt-1 and decrease in PIGF

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Prostaglandins play an important role; Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostaglandin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia

 

Explanation:
In preeclampsia, there is a reduced or absent production of prostacyclin (PGI2) with increased production of thromboxane (TXA2), leading to a decreased prostacyclin-to-thromboxane ratio. This causes vasoconstriction and contributes to the pathophysiology of preeclampsia.

 

Mechanisms of Preeclampsia

 

Abnormal Trophoblastic Invasion

Incomplete remodeling of spiral arteries → Narrow, high-resistance vessels → Reduced placental perfusion → Hypoxia.

Endothelial Dysfunction

sFlt-1 and endoglin release → Inhibition of VEGF and PIGF → Reduced NO production → Vasoconstriction, increased vascular permeability (proteinuria, edema). (Option B ruled out)

Imbalance in Angiogenic Factors

Increased sFlt-1, decreased VEGF and PIGF → Impaired vascular repair and angiogenesis → Endothelial injury. (Option D ruled out)

Oxidative Stress and Inflammation

Hypoxia-reoxygenation injury → ROS and pro-inflammatory cytokines → Endothelial damage, pro-thrombotic state.

Vasoconstriction and Platelet Aggregation

Decreased PGI2 (vasodilator) and increased TXA2 (vasoconstrictor) → Systemic vasoconstriction, microvascular thrombosis.

Multi-Organ Ischemia and Damage

Vasoconstriction and endothelial dysfunction → Reduced blood flow to:

  • Kidneys: Proteinuria (glomerular endotheliosis).
  • Liver: Hepatic ischemia, HELLP syndrome.
  • Brain: Cerebral edema, seizures (eclampsia).
  • Placenta: Fetal growth restriction, abruption. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text:
A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy. Her INR is 3. What is the appropriate next step in management?

LMWH- Low molecular weight heparin

choices.text: Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Stop warfarin and start LMWH

Explanation: As this patient has a history of mechanical mitral valve replacement, she requires anticoagulation therapy. Since she is in the third trimester with an INR of 3, the next step is to switch from warfarin to LMWH to reduce the risk of fetal teratogenicity.

Recommendations for anticoagulants in pregnancy:

  • Pregnancy significantly increases the risk of thromboembolism, but anticoagulation is vital for women with mechanical heart valves to prevent valve thrombosis. (if bioprosthetic valve replacement was done, anticoagulation therapy is not needed)
  • Based on recent guidelines, the dose of warfarin is <5 mg. It may be given in the first trimester, but if the dose is ≥5 mg, it needs to be replaced with LMWH during the first trimester.
  • Warfarin is teratogenic, potentially causing miscarriages, stillbirths, and a constellation of birth defects known as fetal warfarin syndrome. (Option C)
    • Skeletal Abnormalities:
      • Nasal hypoplasia
      • Stippled epiphyses
      • Shortened digits or limb abnormalities.
      • Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).
    • Craniofacial Abnormalities:
      • Microcephaly (small head size), Midface hypoplasia, Cleft palate
    • Neurological Abnormalities:
      • Intellectual disability or developmental delays.
      • Seizures Growth Abnormalities:
    • Eye Abnormalities:
      • Optic atrophy or blindness
      • Strabismus.
  • Heparin, in both unfractionated (UFH) and low-molecular-weight (LMWH) forms, is considered safer for the fetus during pregnancy as it does not cross the placenta.
  • UFH, even at full anticoagulation doses, is considered inadequate for preventing valve thrombosis in pregnant women with mechanical heart valves.
  • LMWH is associated with a lower risk of valve thrombosis compared to UFH, making it a preferred choice for many pregnant women requiring anticoagulation.
  • A common approach is to start LMWH during the first trimester to minimize fetal risks, then switch to warfarin after the first trimester for better valve thrombosis protection. Near term, warfarin is discontinued to reduce bleeding risks during labor, then restarted shortly after delivery.

 

 

  • Regular monitoring of anticoagulation levels
    • PT-INR for warfarin,
    • Anti-Xa levels for LMWH is not normally done, but it is essential during pregnancy.

Stop warfarin and start heparin (Option B): LMWH is preferred over unfractionated heparin due to its longer half-life, once-daily dosing, and fewer side effects. If LMWH is unavailable, unfractionated heparin can be used as an alternative.

Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin (Option D): Aspirin 75-100 mg can be given daily in pregnancy. It can be continued in women with mechanical heart valves if needed for other indications.

questions.text: What is the maternal condition that can cause the observed findings in the baby as presented below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pre-gestational diabetes

Explanation:

  • The given image represents caudal regression syndrome or sacral agenesis which is caused by Pre-gestational diabetes (Option A).
  • Pre-gestational diabetes refers to diabetes that existed prior to pregnancy, whether it is Type 1 or Type 2 diabetes. Poorly controlled diabetes during early pregnancy has been associated with an increased risk of fetal malformations, including caudal regression syndrome and sacral agenesis. High blood sugar levels can disrupt normal fetal development, particularly affecting the development of the lower spine and spinal cord.

Incorrect Options:

Gestational diabetes mellitus (Option B) is a type of diabetes that develops during pregnancy. While poorly controlled GDM can have implications for fetal health, it is less commonly associated with the specific findings of caudal regression and sacral agenesis. The risk of these malformations is higher in pre-gestational diabetes.

Effect of valproate (Option C) is an antiepileptic medication that has been associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects, including spina bifida. However, caudal regression and sacral agenesis are not directly linked to the use of valproate. While there may be an increased risk of certain malformations with valproate use, the specific findings in the question are more strongly associated with maternal diabetes.

ACE inhibitors (Option D) are a class of blood pressure medications that are generally not recommended during pregnancy due to potential fetal complications. However, they are not directly linked to the specific findings of caudal regression and sacral agenesis. Maternal hypertension or the use of ACE inhibitors is not a common cause of these malformations.

questions.text: In which trimester does acute fatty liver manifest most commonly during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Third trimester

Explanation:

  • Acute fatty liver manifests most commonly in the third trimester or early postpartum period.

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP):

Definition

A rare, life-threatening liver disorder that occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy, characterised by microvesicular fatty infiltration of hepatocytes.

Risk Factors
  • First pregnancy
  • Multiple gestations
  • Male fetus
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Maternal obesity
  • Prior history of AFLP

Clinical Features
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Jaundice
  • Malaise and fatigue
  • Anorexia
  • Polydipsia and polyuria
  • Ascites (rare)

Investigation

  • Elevated AST, ALT
  • Elevated bilirubin
  • Hypofibrinogenemia
  • Prolonged clotting time
  • High D-dimer
  • Hypocholesterolemia
  • Microscopy: Microvesicular fatty infiltration

Complications
  • Liver failure
  • Renal failure
  • Coagulopathy
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Encephalopathy

Management
  • Immediate delivery of the baby (definitive treatment)
  • Supportive care for the mother: IV fluids, glucose infusion, and blood products for coagulopathy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman who is pregnant with twins conceived through in vitro fertilization. She is a first-time mother and has reached 38 weeks of gestation. During an antenatal checkup, it was discovered that the first twin is in a breech position, and the mother's blood pressure has been consistently higher than 140/90 mm Hg on two occasions, accompanied by grade 1+ proteinuria. What further actions should be taken?

choices.text: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises
Terminate pregnancy at 40 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Immediate caesarean section

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with two critical concerns:
    1. Preeclampsia: Persistently elevated blood pressure (≥140/90 mm Hg) with proteinuria (1+) is diagnostic of preeclampsia. This condition poses significant risks to both mother and fetus if the pregnancy is prolonged.
    2. Breech presentation of the first twin: A breech presentation, especially in twin pregnancies, increases the risk of complications during vaginal delivery.
  • Given the gestational age of 38 weeks (full-term), immediate caesarean section is the safest approach to ensure the well-being of both the mother and the babies.

Incorrect Options:

Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises (Option A) is not suitable because the patient already has elevated blood pressure on two occasions with proteinuria. These findings are suggestive of preeclampsia, a potentially serious condition that requires prompt management.

Terminating pregnancy at 40 weeks of gestation (Option C) is not appropriate because waiting until 40 weeks of gestation may pose risks to both the mother and the babies, especially considering the presence of preeclampsia and the breech presentation of the first twin.

Inducing labor with PGE2 gel (Option D) is not the recommended approach in this case due to the breech presentation of the first twin. Vaginal delivery in breech presentation can be associated with increased risks, especially in the presence of preeclampsia.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is utilized in contemporary obstetrics for monitoring the fetus of a mother who is Rh-negative and sensitized?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) MCA doppler peak systolic velocity

Explanation:

  • MCA doppler is a specialized ultrasound technique used to assess fetal anemia in Rh-negative sensitized mothers. When an Rh-negative mother is sensitized to Rh-positive fetal red blood cells, maternal antibodies can cross the placenta and cause the destruction of fetal red blood cells, leading to fetal anemia.
  • MCA doppler measures the peak systolic velocity in the middle cerebral artery of the fetus, which correlates with fetal blood flow and oxygenation. A high MCA doppler peak systolic velocity indicates fetal anemia, prompting further evaluation and possible intervention, such as intrauterine transfusion.

Incorrect Options:

A biophysical profile (BPP) (Option A) is a prenatal ultrasound-based assessment that evaluates various parameters of fetal well-being, including fetal movement, fetal tone, fetal breathing, amniotic fluid volume, and reactive fetal heart rate. While BPP is a useful tool for assessing fetal well-being, it is not specifically used for monitoring the fetus of an Rh-negative sensitized mother.

Fetal blood sampling (Option B), also known as cordocentesis or percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS), is a diagnostic procedure in which a sample of fetal blood is obtained from the umbilical cord for laboratory analysis. It is typically performed to assess specific fetal conditions, such as genetic disorders or fetal anemia. Although Rh sensitization can lead to fetal anemia, fetal blood sampling is not the primary investigation used for monitoring Rh-negative sensitized mothers.

There is no specific diagnostic test called "amniospectometry" (Option C) in modern obstetrics. It may refer to the assessment of amniotic fluid volume, which can be evaluated using various methods, including ultrasound measurement of amniotic fluid index (AFI) or single deepest pocket (SDP). While monitoring amniotic fluid volume is important in certain situations, it is not the specific investigation used for

questions.text: What antenatal complication can be anticipated in the mother of the first baby, considering the second baby is a healthy newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Gestational diabetes

Explanation:

As the second baby given in the image is a healthy newborn the condition described in the image is fetal macrosomia

The exact molecular mechanisms behind fetal macrosomia are not fully understood, but fetal hyperinsulinemia is a known contributing factor.

Insulin-like growth factors, leptin, and other adipokines play crucial roles in regulating placental development and function.

Maternal obesity is a significant factor in the development of fetal macrosomia. Additionally, some theories propose that maternal obesity may influence the growth of fetal cardiomyocytes, potentially leading to fetal cardiomyopathy or even congenital heart disease.

Option A) Intake of Phenytoin: Phenytoin is an antiepileptic medication. While the use of certain antiepileptic drugs during pregnancy may pose risks to the developing fetus, such as congenital malformations, this option does not specifically indicate any complications for the mother.

Option C) Intake of ACE inhibitors : ACE inhibitors are a type of medication used to treat conditions like high blood pressure. However, ACE inhibitors are generally contraindicated during pregnancy due to their potential to harm the developing fetus. This option does not mention any complications for the mother specifically.

Option D) Intake of sodium valproate : Sodium valproate is another antiepileptic medication. Like with other antiepileptic drugs, there are concerns about the potential adverse effects on the developing fetus. However, this option does not indicate any specific complications for the mother.

questions.text: During a routine antenatal checkup at 18 weeks of gestation, a pregnant woman's abdominal examination showed that the size of her uterus was equivalent to that of a 16-week gestation. Additionally, an ultrasound detected the presence of oligohydramnios. What is the probable cause for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Renal agenesis

Explanation:

  • Renal agenesis refers to the absence or underdevelopment of one or both kidneys. It can result in reduced or absent urine production, leading to oligohydramnios.
  • Oligohydramnios is characterized by a decreased amniotic fluid volume, which is assessed through ultrasound examination. The decreased amniotic fluid can be observed as a small gestational sac size or less fluid visible around the fetus.

Fetal anemia (Option B) is not a likely cause of oligohydramnios. Fetal anemia can lead to hydrops fetalis, which is characterized by excessive accumulation of fluid in the fetus and may result in polyhydramnios (increased amniotic fluid).

Barter syndrome (Option C) is a rare genetic disorder affecting renal tubular function. It is characterized by abnormal salt and water reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to electrolyte imbalances. While it can cause renal abnormalities, oligohydramnios is not typically associated with Barter syndrome.

Anencephaly (Option D) is a severe congenital malformation where the neural tube fails to close during early development, resulting in the absence of major portions of the brain and skull. Anencephaly is not directly related to oligohydramnios, although it can be associated with other anomalies that may affect amniotic fluid levels.

questions.text: A 29-year-old G2P1 came to the physician at 32 weeks of gestation. She underwent OGTT (75 g of glucose) and her values were fasting 110 mg/dl and 2 hours glucose at 180 mg/dl. Which of the following is the next step regarding the management of this patient?

choices.text: Induce labor due to risk of fetal macrosomia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Admit and start insulin

Explanation:

  • The patient in this scenario is diagnosed with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) based on the oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) values, where the fasting glucose is ≥ 92 mg/dl, which is diagnostic.
  • Insulin is the drug of choice for managing gestational diabetes, as it does not cross the placenta, effectively controlling blood glucose levels in the mother and reducing risks for the fetus.

Incorrect Options:

Oral hypoglycemics (Option A), such as metformin or glyburide, are not typically used as first-line treatment for GDM, particularly because they can cross the placenta and may carry risks for the fetus, including potential hypoglycemia.

Reassurance (Option B) alone is insufficient in the management of gestational diabetes. It requires active monitoring and treatment to maintain appropriate glycemic control to prevent complications such as fetal macrosomia and neonatal hypoglycemia.

Induction of labor (Option D) at 32 weeks is premature and not advisable. The fetal lungs may not be adequately developed, and induction should be considered only after 37 weeks if necessary. The immediate concern should be blood sugar control, not early delivery.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a short cervix undergoes a cervical cerclage procedure.  What is the most likely procedure performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Modified Shirodkar

Explanation: The modified Shirodkar cerclage is a variation of the original Shirodkar procedure, performed for cervical insufficiency in pregnant women with a short or incompetent cervix.

  • In the Shirodkar technique, a suture (usually Mersilene tape) is placed at the level of the internal os after dissecting the bladder and rectum off the cervix, allowing a higher placement than the McDonald’s method.
  • The modified version often uses less extensive bladder dissection or different suture materials, making it technically simpler but still allowing high placement for better cervical support.
  • This technique is especially indicated when a high and strong cerclage is desired, such as in women with significant cervical shortening early in pregnancy.

Cerclage placement in cervical insufficiency:

Transvaginal route:

  • More commonly preferred than the transabdominal route due to the ease of the procedure
  • It is an outpatient procedure and local anaesthesia is preferred.
  • McDonald’s cerclage:
    • More commonly used than Shirodkar’s procedure
    • A purse-string suture with a non-absorbable suture is applied at the cervicovaginal junction.
  • Shirodkar’s cerclage:
    • The cervicovaginal junction is cut and continuous, non-absorbable sutures (using Mersilene tape) are applied at the internal os.

  • Wurm’s stitch (or rescue stitch) is used when a woman presents with cervical dilatation and bulging fetal membranes.

Transabdominal route:

  • It is done only when vaginal cerclage fails or severe cervical anatomical defects are present.
  • Performed less commonly than vaginal cerclage.
  • The suture is placed abdominally at the uterine isthmus
  • The cerclage is left until childbearing is completed and therefore cesarean delivery is required

In both transvaginal and transabdominal procedures, after the placement of cerclage, the patient should be started on progesterone up to 36 weeks+6 days of gestation.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to you with anaemia early in her pregnancy. She is 7 weeks pregnant, as seen on ultrasound. Her haemoglobin level is 9 gm%. When should the iron supplements be started for her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 8 to 10 weeks

  • The pregnant woman here is 7 weeks pregnant and has a haemoglobin level of 9 gm%, for which the treatment is oral iron therapy, and the best time to start is as early as possible, which is 8 to 10 weeks.

Anaemia management protocol for pregnant women

Target Group

Pregnant women registered for antenatal care

Screening and Periodicity

By health service provider at every ANC checkup

Degree

Of anaemia

First Level of Treatment

Follow-up

If No Improvement

Mild anaemia (Hb 10–10.9 g/dl)
  • Two Iron and Folic Acid tablets (60 mg elemental Iron and 500 mcg Folic Acid) daily, orally given by health provider.
  • Parenteral iron (IV Iron Sucrose or Ferric Carboxy Maltose) may be considered for late pregnancy or low compliance cases
  • Every 2 months for treatment compliance.
  • Discontinue treatment if Hb levels normalize, continue prophylactic IFA dose
  • Refer to First Referral Unit (FRU)/District Hospital (DH) if Hb <1 g/dl increases after one month of treatment. Further investigation and management with IV Iron Sucrose/FCM

 

Moderate anaemia (Hb 7–9.9 g/dl)
  • Two Iron and Folic Acid tablets (60 mg elemental Iron and 500 mcg Folic Acid) daily, orally given by health provider.
  • Parenteral iron (IV Iron Sucrose or Ferric Carboxy Maltose) may be considered for late pregnancy or low compliance cases.
  • Every 2 months for treatment compliance. Monthly Hb estimation. Discontinue treatment if Hb levels normalize, continue prophylactic IFA dose.
  • Refer to FRU/DH if Hb <1 g/dl increases after two months of treatment. Further investigation and management with IV Iron Sucrose/FCM

Severe anaemia (Hb 5.0–6.9 g/dl)
  • Managed by the medical officer at PHC/CHC/FRU/DH.
  • Treatment with IV Iron Sucrose/Ferric Carboxymaltose.
  • Immediate hospitalization in the third trimester is recommended at a higher facility.
  • Monthly or as prescribed by the medical officer
  • Follow treatment protocol as prescribed by the medical officer

Early initiation of iron supplementation at the start of 2nd trimester, 10 to 12 weeks (Option A) is preferred to ensure adequate iron stores throughout the pregnancy. But in the given scenario, the woman already suffers from iron deficiency anemia, and hence, the management is started as soon as possible, unlike in a normal pregnancy.

Delaying iron supplementation until after 14 weeks (Option C) would not be optimal for a pregnant woman with anaemia. Early initiation is preferred to prevent further decline in haemoglobin levels and to support fetal development.

Delaying iron supplementation until after 20 weeks (Option D) would not be ideal for a pregnant woman with anaemia. By this time, the woman may have experienced a further decline in haemoglobin levels, which can have adverse effects on both the mother and the developing fetus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. She has a history of epilepsy and has been on anti-epileptic medication for the past 5 years. Which of the following statements regarding folic acid supplementation in patients on anti-epileptic drugs is most accurate?

choices.text: The daily requirement of folic acid is 400 mcg/day
The daily requirement of folic acid is 4 mg/day
The daily requirement of folic acid is 1 mg/day
The daily requirement of folic acid is 500 mcg/day

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The daily requirement of folic acid is 4 mg/day

Explanation:

  • Patients on anti-epileptic medications require higher doses of folic acid
  • This is due to increased metabolism and excretion of folate
  • A replacement dose of 4000 mcg/day (4 mg/day) is recommended to mitigate the risk of deficiency

Clinical Significance:

  • Regular folic acid supplementation is crucial in patients on anti-epileptic medications
  • Proper supplementation helps prevent:
    • Neural tube defects (especially important in women of childbearing age)
    • Megaloblastic anemia
    • Other folate deficiency complications

 

Options A, C, and D suggest inadequate dosing for patients on anti-epileptic medications.

questions.text: A 17-week pregnant woman presents with hypertension, with blood pressure measurements of 140/94 mmHg initially and 144/90 mmHg four hours later. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chronic Hypertension

Explanation: The patient has chronic hypertension based on presentation before 20 weeks of gestation.

Key Features:

  • Pre-existing hypertension presenting in early pregnancy
  • Persistent elevated blood pressure (>140/90 mmHg)
  • Diagnosis made before 20 weeks gestation

Gestational Hypertension (Option A): This requires new-onset hypertension after 20 weeks of gestation. The patient's presentation at 17 weeks excludes this diagnosis as gestational hypertension cannot be diagnosed in early pregnancy.

Acute on Chronic Hypertension (Option C): While the patient has hypertension, there is no evidence of an acute exacerbation as the blood pressure readings are stable. Acuteness in chronic hypertension would show a significant spike in blood pressure values.

Pre-eclampsia (Option D): Pre-eclampsia typically develops after 20 weeks of gestation and requires additional criteria such as proteinuria or evidence of end-organ dysfunction. The patient's early presentation and lack of other symptoms make this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, who is gravida 1, para 1, presents with intermenstrual bleeding for the past 1.5 months. What is the initial investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Urine pregnancy test

Explanation: Urine pregnancy test is the initial test of choice for intermenstrual bleeding evaluation.

Key Features:

  • Detects human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) in urine
  • Sensitivity: 60-70% (sensitive to 150 mIU of HCG)
  • Simple, non-invasive first-line test
  • Rules out pregnancy as cause of bleeding

Ultrasound of the abdomen (Option A): This is not the initial test of choice as it is less sensitive than other methods for early pregnancy detection. While useful for evaluating pelvic pathology, it should be performed after pregnancy status is determined.

Transvaginal ultrasound (Option B): Although TVS provides detailed imaging of the pelvic organs, it is a second-line investigation after a urine pregnancy test. It's more appropriate for evaluating structural causes of bleeding once pregnancy is ruled out.

Endometrial biopsy (Option D): This is an invasive procedure that should only be considered after ruling out pregnancy and completing less invasive investigations. Performing an endometrial biopsy without first confirming pregnancy status could be harmful if the patient is pregnant.

questions.text: A 32-week pregnant woman presents with abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. The uterus is tender. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Abruptio placenta

Explanation: Abruptio placenta is a form of antepartum haemorrhage, where the bleeding occurs due to premature separation of the normally situated placenta.

Pathogenesis:

  • Bleeding occurs due to rupture of blood vessels in the decidua basalis.
  • There is an accumulation of blood in the decidua.
  • This causes the separation of the placenta, leading to
    • Further bleeding.
    • Thrombin generation from haemorrhage triggers the action of matrix metalloproteinases, inflammatory cytokines, and coagulation cascade (high risk of DIC).
    • Fetal distress.

Clinical features:

  • Vaginal bleeding
  • Abdominal pain
  • Uterine tenderness
  • Back pain.
  • Fetal distress.
  • Hypovolemic shock.

Uterine rupture (Option A): This condition typically requires a history of previous cesarean section and presents with palpable fetal parts through the abdominal wall. While it can cause pain and bleeding, the clinical presentation and risk factors don't align with this diagnosis.

Vasa praevia (Option C): This condition characteristically presents with painless bleeding that occurs when membranes rupture. The presence of pain and uterine tenderness makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Placenta praevia (Option D): This condition typically presents with painless, bright red vaginal bleeding without uterine tenderness. The presence of pain and tender uterus in this patient makes placenta praevia an unlikely diagnosis.

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is early cord clamping typically performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Rh-negative mother

Explanation:

  • Early cord clamping is performed in cases of Rh-negative mothers to prevent potential complications related to Rh incompatibility.
  • This approach helps to minimize the risk of hemolytic disease of the newborn by reducing the amount of fetal blood that can mix with the maternal circulation.
  • The appropriate timing of cord clamping varies based on clinical scenarios. Early cord clamping is specifically indicated in Rh-negative mothers to prevent allo-immunization.

Eclamptic patient (Option A): In cases of eclampsia, the priority is often to stabilize the mother and deliver the baby promptly. Early cord clamping is not specifically indicated in this situation; management focuses more on the mother's condition and the baby's immediate needs.

Diabetic patient (Option B): Early cord clamping is not a routine practice specifically for diabetic patients. The management of diabetic pregnancies often focuses on blood sugar control and monitoring, rather than the timing of cord clamping.

Preterm delivery (Option C): For preterm infants, delayed cord clamping is generally preferred to allow for optimal blood transfer from the placenta, which can be beneficial for the infant's health. Early cord clamping is usually not recommended in preterm deliveries unless there are specific complications.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 34 weeks gestation presents for routine prenatal care. Her blood pressure is 118/72 mmHg, and routine laboratory studies reveal a platelet count of 120,000/µL. She is asymptomatic and has no history of bleeding disorders.What is the most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Gestational Thrombocytopenia

Explanation: The most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy is gestational thrombocytopenia, characterized by platelet counts less than 150,000/µL. It accounts for approximately 70-80% of all cases of thrombocytopenia during pregnancy.

Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (Option A): ITP is an autoimmune condition causing platelet destruction but accounts for a much smaller percentage of pregnancy-related thrombocytopenia cases. It typically presents earlier in pregnancy and may require specific treatment.

HELLP Syndrome (Option C): This severe variant of pre-eclampsia includes hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets. The patient's normal blood pressure and absence of other symptoms make this diagnosis unlikely.

Pre-eclampsia (Option D): This hypertensive disorder can cause thrombocytopenia but is not the most common cause. The patient's normal blood pressure and absence of proteinuria exclude this diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause polyhydramnios?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Renal agenesis

Explanation:

Renal agenesis typically leads to oligohydramnios (low amniotic fluid), not polyhydramnios.

Amniotic Fluid Index:

Condition

AFI Range

Description

Normal

5-24 cm

Associated with normal fetal well-being.

Oligohydramnios

< 5 cm

Indicates lower-than-normal amniotic fluid volume and may lead to fetal growth restriction.

Polyhydramnios

> 24 cm

Indicates excessive amniotic fluid accumulation, increasing the risk of preterm labour, placental abruption, and umbilical cord complications.

 

Causes of Oligohydramnios and Polyhydramnios:

Causes

Polyhydramnios

Oligohydramnios

Fetal Factors
  • Fetal anomalies (e.g., anencephaly, esophageal atresia)
  • Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) (Option B)
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Esophageal atresia (Option C)
  • Neural tube defects (Option A)
  • Renal agenesis
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Fetal growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Amnion nodosum

Maternal Factors
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Cardiac disease
  • Renal disease
  • Maternal hypertension
  • Preeclampsia
  • Placental insufficiency

Placental Factors

Chorioangioma

Placental abruption

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with the sign seen on the given USG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Spina bifida

  • The given ultrasound image shows the abnormalities seen in cases of spina bifida.

Spina bifida

  • It is one of the most common neural tube defects
  • Types of spina bifida:
    • Occulta
    • Closed
    • Menigocoele
    • Myelomenigocoele

Ultrasound findings in spina bifida

Cranial abnormalities

  • Cisterna magna obliteration
  • Banana sign: Compression or flattening of posterior cerebellar surface, giving a crescentic appearance
  • Lemon sign: Concave deformity of the frontal bones
  • Hydrocephaly

Fetal face

  • Cleft lip
  • Cleft palate

Rectal prolapse (Option B) is usually diagnosed clinically. Dynamic cystocolpoproctography can be used for detection.

Uterine prolapse (Option C) is seen by the weakness of supporting structures in the USG.

Cervical carcinoma (Option D) is diagnosed more precisely with the help of CT and MRI.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida with a low-risk pregnancy presents at 39 weeks + 6 days with labour pains. Her vitals are stable. On PV, her cervix is 3cm dilated and 60% effaced. The fetal head is at -3 station and membranes are felt as a bag of worms beneath the head. What is the appropriate course of management?

choices.text: Rupture of membranes and confirm cord prolapse
Proceed with emergency LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section)

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Proceed with emergency LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section)

Explanation:

The situation in this scenario is cord presentation, and since the baby is term and the cervix is not fully dilated, the best management for this case is to proceed to cesarean section as definitive management.

  • Cord presentation involves the umbilical cord being felt below the presenting part without membrane rupture.
  • Both cord prolapse and cord presentation are obstetric emergencies, and the management is immediate delivery by emergency LSCS.
  • The presenting part can be elevated to relieve cord compression (positional or with fingers if possible) till delivery is started or if the patient needs to be transferred.

Management of cord prolapse is based on:

  • Baby's status (living or dead)
  • Baby's maturity
  • Degree

Living baby

Definitive treatment

 

Cesarean Section (Best option for mature, living babies)

If immediate Safe Vaginal Delivery Possible:
  • Head Engaged: Complete delivery with forceps (ventouse is less ideal).
  • Breech Presentation: Complete delivery by breech extraction.

If immediate Safe Vaginal Delivery Not Possible

 
  • Minimise cord pressure until definitive treatment or transfer to a suitable hospital.
  • Stop any ongoing oxytocin infusion.
  • Bladder Filling: Use a Foley catheter to fill the bladder with 400–750 mL fluid—empty the bladder before cesarean delivery.
  • Postural Treatment: Use an elevated Sims position with a pillow or wedge
  • Cord Replacement: Place the cord back into the vagina to reduce vasospasm.

Baby Dead

 

Allow labour to proceed for spontaneous delivery.

 

 

Rupturing the membranes (Option A) in this situation can lead to cord prolapse, which is a serious obstetric emergency. It is not advisable to intentionally rupture the membranes without a clear assessment and appropriate management plan.

Oxytocin (Option B) is not the immediate solution in the presence of a prolapsed cord. The focus should be on relieving pressure on the cord and expediting delivery through emergency LSCS rather than initiating labor augmentation.

Wait and watch (Option D) is not an option here since this case can proceed to cord prolapse and further complications endangering the baby.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant female in her first trimester presents to the OPD for a regular antenatal checkup. During blood type screening, potential ABO incompatibility is discussed. The healthcare provider explains that certain antibody types are less concerning than others during pregnancy. ABO incompatibility does not occur due to which antibody in her case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D) IgM

Explanation:

The clinical scenario addresses maternal-fetal ABO incompatibility and antibody transfer across the placenta:

  • IgM antibodies cannot cross the placenta due to their large molecular size
  • Placental transfer is selective and depends on antibody structure.
  • Only IgG antibodies can effectively cross the placenta
  • ABO incompatibility occurs primarily through IgG-mediated hemolysis

 

IgA (Option A): While IgA antibodies are not known to cross the placenta, it is not the primary antibody class that's excluded from crossing the placenta.

IgG (Option B): IgG is the only antibody that is known to cross the placenta, making it the primary concern in blood type incompatibility.

IgD (Option C): IgD antibodies are not known to cross the placenta, it is not the primary antibody class that's excluded from crossing the placenta.

questions.text: A woman presents to you at 36 weeks of gestation with complaints of breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension. Fetal movements are normal on examination, fetal parts are not easily felt, and fetal heartbeat is heard but muffled. Her symphysis-fundal height is 41 cm. Her abdomen is tense but not tender. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Polyhydramnios

  • The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of polyhydramnios, characterized by excessive amniotic fluid accumulation.

Polyhydramnios

  • In pregnancies without diabetes or hypertension, fetal anomalies such as anencephaly are commonly associated with polyhydramnios, occurring in about 50% of cases.
  • The excessive production of amniotic fluid can be attributed to:
    • Leakage from the exposed meninges
    • Lack of fetal swallowing reflex
    • Inhibition of fetal antidiuretic hormone, resulting in increased fetal urine output
  • It can be categorized as follows based on the Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI):
    • Mild: AFI = 25 to 29.9 cm
    • Moderate: AFI = 30 to 34.9 cm
    • Severe: AFI ≥ 35 cm

Causes

Polyhydramnios

Fetal Factors
  • Fetal anomalies (e.g., anencephaly, esophageal atresia) (Option A)
  • Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)
  • Hydrops fetalis

Maternal Factors
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Cardiac disease
  • Renal disease

Placental Factors

Chorioangioma

 

Abruptio placenta (Option A)refers to the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall before delivery. It typically presents with sudden onset of painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and a firm/tender uterus.

Hydrocephalus (Option B) refers to the accumulation of excess cerebrospinal fluid within the ventricles of the brain. It can cause an enlarged head circumference in the fetus and may present with additional symptoms such as macrocephaly, bulging fontanelles, and neurological signs.

Fetal-maternal ascites (Option D), also known as fetal hydrops, is a condition characterized by abnormal fluid accumulation in both the fetal and maternal compartments. Various factors, such as fetal cardiac abnormalities or chromosomal abnormalities, can cause it. While it can present with abdominal distension, it typically involves additional signs such as oedema, pleural effusion, or skin changes.

questions.text: A young primigravida at 32 weeks gestation was admitted since her BP was 150/90 mmHg and urine dipstick was 2+ on antenatal checkup. On examination, she has pedal edema. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Preeclampsia

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with elevated blood pressure (150/90 mmHg), proteinuria (2+ on urine dipstick), and pedal edema, which are characteristic signs of Preeclampsia.

Preeclampsia:

  • Types of Preeclampsia:
    • Early-Onset Preeclampsia:
      • Occurs at <34 weeks gestation.
      • Etiology: Defective placenta due to altered trophoblast invasion and placental ischemia.
      • Features: Placental infarcts, arterial sclerosis, and hypoperfusion.
    • Late-Onset Preeclampsia:
      • Occurs at ≥34 weeks gestation.
      • Etiology: Healthy placenta interacting with maternal factors, causing microvascular damage and endothelial dysfunction.
      • Features: Maintained placental perfusion; managed expectantly until 37 weeks if stable.
  • Clinical Presentations:
    • New-onset headache unresponsive to medication.
    • Visual disturbances.
    • Right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, often with nausea or vomiting.
    • Shortness of breath.
    • Worsened swelling beyond baseline pregnancy-related symptoms.
  • Physical Findings:
    • Elevated blood pressure:
      • SBP ≥140 mmHg or DBP ≥90 mmHg on two measurements at least 4 hours apart.
      • Severe hypertension: SBP ≥160 mmHg or DBP ≥110 mmHg.
    • Edema: Dependent (lower extremities) or independent (face, hands).
    • Lung examination for pulmonary disturbances.
    • Tenderness in the right upper quadrant or epigastric area.
  • Laboratory Tests:
    • Proteinuria: Urine dipstick ≥2+, 24-hour collection ≥300 mg, or protein/creatinine ratio ≥0.3.
    • Thrombocytopenia: Platelet count <100 K/mm³.
    • Impaired Liver Function: Liver enzymes >2 times the upper limit of normal.
    • Renal Insufficiency: Serum creatinine ≥1.1 mg/dL or double baseline levels.
  • Management:
    • Antihypertensive Therapy:
      • For severe hypertension (SBP ≥160 mmHg or DBP ≥110 mmHg):
        • IV Medications: Labetalol, hydralazine.
        • Oral Medications: Immediate-release nifedipine.
      • For maintenance:
        • PO Medications: Labetalol, extended-release nifedipine, or clonidine.
    • Seizure Prophylaxis:
      • First-Line: IV magnesium sulfate.
      • Alternatives (if contraindicated): Levetiracetam or benzodiazepines for seizure treatment.
    • Definitive Treatment: Delivery of the fetus is the only definitive cure.
    • Delivery Timing:
      • Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia without Severe Features: Deliver at 37 weeks.
      • Severe Features at ≥34 weeks: Delivery after maternal stabilization.
      • Severe Features <34 weeks: Expectant management with close monitoring and antenatal steroids for fetal lung maturation if stable.

 

Placenta previa (Option A) is characterized by painless vaginal bleeding and the placenta covering the cervix, it does not typically present with high blood pressure, proteinuria, or pedal edema as seen in this case.

Placenta abruptio (Option B) typically presents with abdominal pain and painful vaginal bleeding due to placental detachment, whereas the patient’s signs of pedal edema and proteinuria are more suggestive of preeclampsia.

Spontaneous Abortion (Option C) occurs in the early stages of pregnancy and is associated with vaginal bleeding and cramping, not high blood pressure or proteinuria.

questions.text: The screening method for GDM recommended in India is done between:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 24-28 weeks of gestation

Explanation:

  • The screening method for GDM recommended in India is done between 24-28 weeks of gestation.

One-step approach recommended by WHO and IAD PSG (International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Group):

  • It is done in all pregnant females at 24-28 weeks.
  • It is used both for screening and diagnostic purposes.
  • The patient is advised to have an unrestricted diet for 72 hours, followed by overnight fasting, and then 75 gm of glucose is given.
  • A total of 3 samples are taken:
    • 1st sample: Fasting sample.
    • 2nd sample: After 1 hour of 75 gm of glucose.
    • 3rd sample: After 2 hours of 75 gm of glucose.
  • Interpretation: If any 1 value is abnormal, the patient is considered as having gestational diabetes.
